latest news.eng_title: Metro Atlanta resident diagnosed with measles, DPH says
latest news.summary: The Georgia Department of Public Health (DPH) has confirmed a fifth reported measles case in the state in 2024. The infected individual, a metro Atlanta resident, was exposed while traveling outside the country and was not fully vaccinated. DPH is identifying anyone who may have been in contact with them to prevent the spread of the virus. According to DPH, measles can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, which provides immunity to 95% of people who receive a single dose and 98% with a second dose. Symptoms of measles include high fever, cough, runny nose, and a rash of tiny, red spots that start at the head and spread to the rest of the body. The CDC recommends children receive their first dose of the MMR vaccine between 12 and 15 months of age and a second dose between 4 and 6 years old.
latest news.title: Metro Atlanta resident diagnosed with measles, DPH says

latest news.eng_title: Oregon's measles outbreak grows to largest since 1991
latest news.summary: Oregon's measles outbreak has grown to 30 cases, surpassing the 2019 outbreak with 28 cases, and is now the largest reported outbreak since 1991. The outbreak is centered in Marion County, with 20 cases, and all cases have been unvaccinated individuals, with two hospitalized. Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority's Public Health Division, stated, 'We don't have enough vaccinated people to stop the transmission, and so it goes on.' The outbreak is attributed to a rise in vaccine exemptions, with non-medical exemption rates for kindergartners increasing from 1% to 8.8% since 2000. Health officials warn that unvaccinated students who are exposed to measles may have to miss school for up to 21 days, and that complications from the disease can lead to lifelong effects including hearing loss, deafness and intellectual disabilities. According to the CDC, 87% of measles cases in 2024 involved individuals who were either unvaccinated or had an unknown vaccination status.
latest news.title: Oregon's measles outbreak grows to largest since 1991

latest news.eng_title: 5th case of measles reported in metro Atlanta

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
latest news.summary: Georgia health officials have confirmed the fifth case of measles in metro Atlanta this year. The individual, who was not fully vaccinated, was exposed to the virus while traveling out of the country. Officials are working to identify anyone who may have been in contact with the person while they were infectious. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, there have been around 220 cases of the virus in 27 jurisdictions this year, nearly quadruple the number from 2023. The CDC recommends that all Georgia children receive a dose of the MMR vaccine between 12 and 15 months and a second dose between the ages of 4 and 6 to prevent infection. Symptoms of measles include fevers, coughs, runny noses, and watery eyes, followed by a red rash that spreads to the body. The CDC advises those infected to avoid public places and contact their doctor immediately.
latest news.title: 5th case of measles reported in metro Atlanta

latest news.eng_title: Georgia health officials link a 5th case of measles to travel
latest news.summary: The Georgia Department of Public Health (DPH) has confirmed a fifth case of measles in Georgia this year, a metro Atlanta resident who was exposed while traveling outside the U.S. The individual was 'not fully vaccinated,' according to DPH. Health officials are working to identify and contact anyone who may have been exposed to the individual with measles to prevent further spread. Measles symptoms appear 7 to 14 days after contact with the virus and typically include high fever, cough, runny nose, and watery eyes or conjunctivitis. The best known symptom is a rash of tiny red spots that typically start at the head and spread to the rest of the body. According to the CDC, measles is so contagious that if one person has it, up to 90% of the people close to that person who are not immune will also become infected. The MMR vaccine is very effective and can prevent illness, with about 95% of people developing immunity to all three viruses after a single dose and 98% after a second dose.
latest news.title: Georgia health officials link a 5th case of measles to travel

latest news.eng_title: Measles Cases Rise Sharply in Baden-Württemberg
latest news.summary: The number of measles cases in Baden-Württemberg has increased to 24 since the beginning of the year, a significant jump from the five cases reported in 2023. This trend is also observed in Europe, where the number of measles cases is rising sharply. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), measles is one of the most contagious diseases. The majority of cases in Baden-Württemberg were contracted abroad or through contact with someone who brought the disease back from abroad. The state's health ministry recommends vaccination, citing the high contagiousness of the disease and the risk of severe complications, including death. The ministry notes that the number of measles cases is returning to pre-pandemic levels, with 73 cases reported in 2019 and 23 in 2020. Leif Eric Sander, an immunologist at the Charité Berlin, stated, 'One person can infect between 12 and 18 others with measles.' He emphasized that a measles infection can cause lasting damage, such as vision impairment, and in severe cases, be fatal. A measles vaccination provides protection against infection and prevents the spread of the virus.
latest news.title: Baden-Württemberg Fälle von Masern steigen in BW sprunghaft an - Ansteckung häufig im Ausland

latest news.eng_title: Measles cases surge in Bavaria, reaching pre-Corona levels

Organization: Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety

latest news.summary: Measles cases are on the rise in Bavaria, with the number of reported cases reaching pre-Corona levels. According to the Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety, there were 57 reported measles cases in the first eight months of 2024, compared to only five cases in the same period last year. This is a significant increase from the 11 cases reported in 2023 and the four cases reported in 2022. 'The number of measles cases is approaching the level before the Corona pandemic,' said Gerlach. 'In 2019, there were 75 measles cases reported in the state. The current numbers show that we are now approaching the level of the pre-Corona years.' Gerlach attributed the increase to the reduced contact and protective measures during the Corona pandemic. She emphasized the importance of vaccination, particularly for children under the age of five, who are most vulnerable to the disease. 'Masern are a highly contagious disease that can lead to severe complications and are often underestimated as a harmless children's disease,' she warned. 'The vaccine prevents both infection and transmission very well. With two timely measles vaccinations, parents protect their child's health and also make an important contribution to community protection.' According to the data from the Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety, about half of the reported measles cases in 2024 came from nine individual households where unvaccinated people live.
latest news.title: Hochansteckende Krankheit breitet sich wieder aus – Experte rät zu Schutzimpfung

latest news.eng_title: Measles Cases on the Rise in Bavaria

Organization: Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety
Title: Health Minister

latest news.summary: According to the Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety (LGL), there have been 57 reported cases of measles in Bavaria as of August 5, 2024. This is a significant increase from previous years, with only 5 cases reported in the same period last year. 'We are seeing a return to pre-COVID-19 levels,' said Bavaria's Health Minister Judith Gerlach. 'The current numbers are likely due to the reduced measures and decreased contact during the pandemic.' Gerlach emphasized the importance of vaccination, particularly for children, as measles is a highly contagious disease that can lead to severe complications. 'The vaccination is very effective in preventing both infection and transmission,' she said. 'With two timely measles vaccinations, parents can protect their child's health and also contribute to community protection.' Data from the LGL shows that about half of the reported measles cases this year were linked to nine households where unvaccinated individuals lived.
latest news.title: Maserninfektionen in Bayern nehmen zu

latest news.eng_title: Measles Outbreaks in the US: The Importance of Vaccination
latest news.summary: The US is experiencing outbreaks of measles, with 58 cases confirmed in seven outbreaks between January and March 2024. The majority of cases, 93%, were related to international travel. Measles is a serious disease that can cause pneumonia and, in rare cases, encephalitis, which can lead to seizures, hearing loss, intellectual disability, and even death. The disease is highly contagious, with 9 out of 10 people around an infected person also becoming infected if they are not immune. According to Dr. Michelle Goveia, a pediatric vaccination expert, 'vaccines have helped protect millions of people worldwide from many serious diseases.' However, vaccines only work when people get vaccinated. The M-M-R II vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps, and rubella, is administered as an injection and is recommended for children over one year old. It is essential to stay up-to-date with recommended vaccinations, especially during outbreaks, to prevent the spread of diseases. Dr. Rabia Agha, director of the Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases at Maimonides Children's Hospital in Brooklyn, New York, warns that 'many people do not realize how contagious measles is. The virus can remain in the air for up to two hours after an infected person leaves a space.' It is crucial to maintain good vaccination habits to prevent the spread of diseases and protect vulnerable individuals, such as those with weakened immune systems.
latest news.title: Vacunación infantil: Por qué es importante para sus hijos y la comunidad - The Pagosa Springs Sun

news knowledge.eng_title: Increasing spread of measles is becoming inevitable
news knowledge.summary: The United States is experiencing a significant increase in measles cases, with 159 confirmed cases in 2024, almost triple the 2023 total of 58. The CDC states that 84% of the cases were either unvaccinated or had an unknown vaccination status. Measles is a highly contagious virus that poses a significant risk to young children, pregnant women, and the immunocompromised. The virus can live for up to two hours on surfaces and air, and people can be contagious for up to four days before symptoms appear. The World Health Organization reports that worldwide measles rates increased 18% to 9 million confirmed cases in 2022, resulting in 136,000 deaths, mostly among children. The increased migration of people from areas with high measles rates to the US, combined with vaccine hesitancy, makes further spread of the virus inevitable. As the article states, 'it hasn't gotten any better with age'.
news knowledge.title: Increasing spread of measles is becoming inevitable

news knowledge.eng_title: U.S. Measles Cases Jump Sharply in 2024

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

news knowledge.summary: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the number of measles cases in the U.S. has tripled in 2024 compared to last year, with 188 cases reported across 25 states, New York City, and the District of Columbia as of July 25. Approximately 95% of cases have involved individuals who were either unvaccinated, had an unknown vaccination status, or had received only one dose of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. The CDC reports that nearly two-thirds of measles cases this year have been associated with outbreaks, with the largest outbreak occurring at a migrant shelter in Chicago in March, resulting in 57 cases. Measles is a highly contagious disease that can infect up to 90% of people who are unprotected if they come in contact with someone with the illness. The CDC notes that the number of measles cases has jumped periodically due to a decline in vaccination rates among schoolchildren and an overall increase in cases globally.
news knowledge.title: U.S. Measles Cases Jump Sharply in 2024

news knowledge.summary: Measles cases in the U.S. have surged in 2024, with 188 reported cases across 25 states, New York City, and the District of Columbia as of July 25, according to the CDC. This is more than triple the 58 cases recorded in all of 2023. The majority of cases, 95%, have involved individuals who were unvaccinated, had an unknown vaccination status, or had received only one dose of the MMR vaccine. Health officials have reported 13 measles outbreaks, with the largest occurring at a migrant shelter in Chicago in March, resulting in 57 cases. Measles is a highly contagious disease that can infect up to 90% of people who are unprotected if they come in contact with someone with the illness. 'Measles was declared eliminated in the U.S. in 2000, thanks in large part to the success of an extensive vaccination program,' said the CDC. However, in recent years, the number of measles cases has jumped periodically due to a decline in vaccination rates among schoolchildren and an overall increase in cases globally.
news knowledge.title: Measles Cases Jump Sharply in 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: CDC Says Measles Cases Already Triple 2023 Total

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

news knowledge.summary: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has reported that the number of measles cases in the U.S. has already tripled the total for 2023, with 188 cases reported in 27 jurisdictions as of July 25, 2024. The majority of cases (123 of 188) are associated with outbreaks, a significant increase from 2023. Experts attribute the uptick to declining vaccination rates in the U.S. and a rise in measles cases worldwide. Around 85% of cases were either unvaccinated or had an unknown vaccination status, with many linked to international travel.
news knowledge.title: CDC Says Measles Cases Already Triple 2023 Total

news knowledge.source_id: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
news knowledge.summary: The United States has maintained measles elimination since 2023, with 338 cases reported from January 2020 to March 2024. Most cases were import-associated, and the surveillance system is performing well. However, the rapid increase in reported cases in the first quarter of 2024 represents a renewed threat to elimination. The majority of importations were from countries in the Eastern Mediterranean and African WHO regions, where measles incidence is high. Global estimates suggest that first-dose measles vaccination coverage has declined, leaving almost 22 million children susceptible to measles. Maintaining high national and local MMR vaccination coverage is crucial to sustaining measles elimination. The risk of widespread measles transmission remains low due to high population immunity, but efforts are needed to increase routine MMR vaccination coverage and rapidly investigate suspected measles cases to maintain elimination.
news knowledge.title: Measles  --  United States, January 1, 2020-March 28, 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: U.S. Measles Cases Are Already Triple Those of Last Year

Organization: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

news knowledge.summary: According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the number of measles cases reported in the United States this year has already tripled that of last year. As of July 2024, 188 cases have been confirmed in 26 states and Washington, D.C., with 93 people hospitalized, mostly children under the age of 5. In comparison, there were only 58 cases reported in all of 2023.
news knowledge.title: U.S. Measles Cases Are Already Triple Those of Last Year

news knowledge.eng_title: Measles cases surge to triple last year's — with 5 months to go
news knowledge.summary: The United States has seen a significant surge in measles cases in 2024, with 188 reported cases compared to 58 in 2023. Approximately 65% of this year's cases are associated with outbreaks, and about half of cases required hospitalization. According to the CDC, 85% of infected individuals were unvaccinated or unknown, while 10% had received one MMR vaccination and 5% had received two doses. Medical professionals emphasize that the risk of contracting measles is extremely low after getting vaccinated.
news knowledge.title: Measles cases surge to triple last year's — with 5 months to go

news knowledge.eng_title: Measles Cases Triple in the US, CDC Reports

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

news knowledge.summary: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the number of measles cases in the United States has increased significantly, with 188 cases reported in 2024, compared to 58 cases in 2023. This represents a tripling of cases from last year. The CDC defines an outbreak as three or more cases linked together, and there have been 13 outbreaks in 2024, compared to 4 in 2023. About half of the cases this year have required hospitalization for isolation or management of complications. The CDC reports that 85% of those infected this year were not vaccinated or their vaccination status was unknown, while 10% had received the MMR vaccine and 5% had received two doses. Healthcare professionals emphasize that the risk of contracting measles is extremely low after being vaccinated. Measles is a highly contagious and serious disease that can cause severe complications, including death, especially in children.
news knowledge.title: Les cas de rougeole ont plus que triplé l'année dernière, à cinq mois de l'épidémie

Approximately 65% of cases are associated with outbreaks, and about half of cases required hospitalization. The CDC reports that 85% of infected individuals were unvaccinated or unknown, while 10% had received one MMR vaccination and 5% had received two doses. Medical professionals emphasize that the risk of contracting measles is extremely low after getting vaccinated. Measles is a highly contagious and serious airborne disease that can lead to severe complications and even death, especially in children.
